Learn and play at the same time: Weâ€™re excited to announce that â€˜The Nassaus of Bredaâ€™ has won a Siegel in the Comenius Edumedia Awards for â€˜game-based digital educational mediaâ€™! At the permanent exhibition in Stedelijk Museum Breda, visitors explore the rich history of the Nassau family through our engaging and playful family trail. Through interactive games they experience what it was like to live, work and fight in the past. Children can follow the playful stamp trail, assembling a group portrait of local figures who all left their mark on Nassau history. At each stop, they hear, do, or experience the Nassau story and collect 13 cheerful stamps (illustrated by Jose Luis Garcia Lechner). Another highlight is a game about table manners, inspired by Erasmusâ€™ etiquette, where children get to choose whether statements like â€˜Itâ€™s acceptable to laugh loudly during dinnerâ€™ are true or false. The story of the Holocaust is told in many museums and memorial sites, often in impressive ways. But how to highlight the personal stories, showing them as individuals and not merely as victims? The â€˜glass teardropsâ€™ commemorate the lives of more Holocaust victims and restore their humanity. Each teardrop tells the story of someone who was imprisoned at the Hollandsche Schouwburg deportation site. By holding an audio device up to the drops, visitors can listen to the victimsâ€™ eyewitness accounts. One of the drops contains the story of Salo Muller. Along with his parents, he was transported to the Hollandsche Schouwburg. Here he was torn from his parents and taken to the Jewish kindergarten across the street. It was a traumatic experience for him, leaving him completely distressed for four days. Eventually Salo Muller was smuggled away through the teacher training college next door, to go into hiding. Tragically, the now 87-year-old Salo never beheld his parents again. â€œThe more you contemplate about it, the more beautiful, the more emotional it becomes. A single droplet falls and disappears. Yet this one, fortunately, endures.â€ â€“ Salo Muller for AT5, 5 February 2024 Read more: https://lnkd.in/eh4mmVJb Together with OPERA Amsterdam Joods Cultureel Kwartier Beersnielsen Lichtontwerpers Shosho Bruns Ata Tech B.V. #studiolouter #nationaalholocaustmuseum #exhibitiondesign #glassteardrops #studiolouter #touchedbystudiolouter ğŸ“· pictures by Thijs Wolzak and Mike Bink fotografie

How does Emotion Design enhance the storytelling in â€˜The Ship of Dreamsâ€™? And how does technology aid in achieving its creative goals and engaging the public? Our Content Designer Eline Koning had the honor of discussing these questions - and much more - at the 23rd online edition of The Best in Heritage. She spoke with Gabriela da Rocha about â€˜The Ship of Dreamsâ€™ project at Titanic Belfast. This project won numerous awards, including the THEA Award (2023), the F@IMP Claude Nicole Hocqard Grand Prize of Avicom (2023) and was shortlisted for the 2024 Museum & Heritage Awards in the â€˜Permanent Exhibition of the Yearâ€™ category. In 2023 we completed an ambitious makeover at Titanic Belfast, designed to connect future generations to the history of the Titanic. Visitor input guided the project, shaping sensory and immersive design. Amid the immersive trend, the challenge was to make the experience meaningful and tell a story; to go beyond the wow-effect. Using Studio Louterâ€™s Emotion Design method, our team combined innovative technology with emotional storytelling to deeply engage the visitors. We created the project together with OPERA Amsterdam Shosho DHA Designs Marcom DJ Willrich Ltd Fiction Factory 181. How can we expose the full extent of the crimes by the Nazis in unvarnished, unfiltered form? The â€˜wallpaper of crimesâ€™ lists an overwhelming stream of Naziâ€™s rules and laws enacted to carry out the Holocaust. These regulations paper the walls of the galleries from floor to ceiling, emphasizing that the Holocaust was not a coincidence of anonymous crimes. It was a deliberate, systematic act of dehumanization and mass murder, largely committed in broad daylight. In the Netherlands, Jews were banned from visiting parks, zoos, cafÃ©s, restaurants, hotels, pensions, cabarets, cinemas, sport clubs, concerts, public libraries and museums. They were prohibited from owning or operating vehicles or to steer them. A curfew confined them to their homes from 8 pm to 6 am, unable to use bicycles or public transportation. This list continues, gallery after gallery, meter after meter. â€œThe museum ingeniously reveals how the exclusion of Jews was escalated step by step. (â€¦) As a visitor, you feel the weight of the words pressing down on you.â€ â€“ NRC, 8 March 2024 Read more: https://lnkd.in/eh4mmVJb Together with Opera Amsterdam B.V. The new National Holocaust Museum chose to take the personal perspective of the victims as its starting point. But how do these stories become a museum exhibit? We set ourselves a task given to us by the handwritten plea of three victims: donâ€™t forget us! We began by rehumanizing the victims through the â€˜forget-me-notsâ€™ - nineteen uniquely designed display cases. A personal object, a photographic portrait, a brief text and an audio fragment paint the picture of a precious individual lost in the Holocaust. One such story is that of nine-year-old Rosa Schlamowitz. Her parents, still haunted by the memory of Kristallnacht, made the painful decision to send her away to ensure her safety. Before Rosa left for the Netherlands in 1939, Rosaâ€™s mother gave her a silver medallion to take with her. Rosa did not survive the Holocaust. â€œEighty years on, the National Holocaust Museum is doing what many Dutch failed to do just after the war: truly seeing the victims of the Holocaust, as human beings.â€ â€“ Trouw, 5 maart 2024 Read more about the project: https://lnkd.in/eh4mmVJb Together with Opera Amsterdam B.V.
